Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Situation2: They notice minor inconsistencies in a building plan that are unlikely to cause immediate issues.
Story: I glance at my phone, seeing his message: “Let’s pick a night for dinner this week—just us.” My heart lifts. We haven’t had a real date in ages, and for once, our schedules actually align. I imagine us laughing over pasta, the city lights outside, his hand in mine. But as I close my laptop, my eyes catch the building plans spread across my desk. There’s a nagging detail—a measurement that doesn’t quite add up. It’s probably nothing, but as the architect, I know even small errors can snowball. My boss expects me to catch these things, to ensure every line and number means safety for future families. I feel the weight of both roles pressing in. He wants my time, my undivided attention. My work demands vigilance, responsibility. I want to be present for him, but I can’t ignore the plans. My mind races, torn between the warmth of his arms and the cold precision of blueprints, knowing I can’t give both what they deserve tonight.
